revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Wanda Sykes | image = Wanda Sykes 2010 GLAAD Media Awards.jpg | caption = Sykes at the 2010 [[GLAAD Media Awards]] | birth_date = March 7, 1964 (age 54) | birth_place = [[Portsmouth, Virginia]], U.S | residence = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], U.S.
[[Media, Pennsylvania]], U.S. | alma_mater = [[Hampton University]] | occupation = Actress, comedienne, writer | years_active = 1987–present | spouse = {{marriage|[[Dave Hall (record producer)|Dave Hall]]|1991|1998|reason=divorced}}
{{marriage|Alex Niedbalski|2008}} | children = 2 | website = {{Official website|http://www.wandasykes.com}} }} '''Wanda Sykes''' (born March 7, 1964) is an American actress, comedian, and writer. She was first recognized for her work as a writer on ''[[The Chris Rock Show]]'', for which she won a [[Primetime Emmy Award]] in 1999. In 2004, ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' named Sykes as one of the 25 funniest people in America.{{cite news|title=The Best of the Rest|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,600311_2,00.html|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=March 19, 2004|accessdate=December 25, 2008}} She is also known for her role as Barb Baran on [[CBS]]' ''[[The New Adventures of Old Christine]]'' (2006–10) and for appearances on [[HBO]]'s ''[[Curb Your Enthusiasm]]'' (2001–11). Aside from her television appearances, Sykes has also had a career in film, appearing in ''[[Monster-in-Law]]'' (2005), ''[[My Super Ex-Girlfriend]]'' (2006), ''[[Evan Almighty]]'' (2007) and ''[[License to Wed]]'' (2007), as well as voicing characters in the animated films ''[[Over the Hedge (film)|Over the Hedge]]'' (2006), ''[[Brother Bear 2]]'' (2006), ''[[Rio (2011 film)|Rio]]'' (2011), ''[[Ice Age: Continental Drift]]'' (2012) and ''[[Ice Age: Collision Course]]'' (2016). ==Early life== Born in [[Portsmouth, Virginia]],Belcher, Walt (August 17, 2001). "Wanda Sykes' Star is Rising". ''The Tampa Tribune''. p. 3. Sykes' family moved to [[Maryland]] when she was in third grade.Bonko, Larry (January 6, 2005). "Wild, blue Wanda". ''The Virginian-Pilot'' (Norfolk, Virginia). p. E9. Her mother, Marion Louise (née Peoples), worked as a banker, and her father, Harry Ellsworth Sykes, was a [[Colonel (United States)|U.S. Army colonel]] employed at [[the Pentagon]].{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/20/arts/television/wanda-sykes-finds-ancestors-thanks-to-henry-louis-gates-jr.html | work=The New York Times | first=Felicia R. | last=Lee | title=Wanda Sykes Finds Ancestors Thanks to Henry Louis Gates Jr | date=March 19, 2012}} Sykes' family history was researched for an episode of the 2012 PBS genealogy program ''Finding Your Roots With [[Henry Louis Gates Jr.]]'' Her ancestry was traced back to a 1683 court case involving her paternal ninth great-grandmother Elizabeth Banks, a free white woman and indentured servant, who gave birth to a biracial child, Mary Banks, fathered by a slave, who inherited her mother's free status. According to historian [[Ira Berlin]], a specialist in the history of American slavery, the Sykes family history is "the only such case that I know of in which it is possible to trace a black family rooted in freedom from the late 17th century to the present."{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/20/arts/television/wanda-sykes-finds-ancestors-thanks-to-henry-louis-gates-jr.html |title=Family Tree’s Startling Roots |date=March 19, 2012 |work=The New York Times |first=Felicia R. |last=Lee}} Sykes attended [[Arundel High School]]{{cite web|last=Katz|first=Lee Michael|title=Funny Girl|url=http://www.washingtonian.com/articles/capitalcomment/15960.html|work=Washingtonian.com|accessdate=June 11, 2010}} in [[Gambrills, Maryland]], and went on to graduate from [[Hampton University]], where she earned a [[bachelor of science]] degree in marketing and is a member of [[Alpha Kappa Alpha]]. After college, her first job was as a [[procurement|contracting specialist]] at the [[National Security Agency]],{{cite web | url=https://movies.yahoo.com/movie/contributor/1804481088/bio |title=Wanda Sykes Biography | work=Yahoo! Movies | publisher=AEC One Group Stop, Inc. | year=2008 | accessdate=December 11, 2008 }} where she worked for five years.{{cite news |title=Black and Gay Like Me |first=Ari |last=Karpel |work=The Advocate |date=March 2009 |issue=1024 |url=http://www.advocate.com/issue_story_ektid71760.asp }} == Career == Not completely satisfied with her role with the NSA, Sykes began her stand-up career at a Coors Light Super Talent Showcase in Washington, DC, where she performed for the first time in front of a live audience in 1987.{{cite web | url=http://www.nndb.com/people/626/000044494/ | title= Wanda Sykes | work=The Notable Names Database | year=2008 | accessdate=December 29, 2008}} She continued to hone her talents at local venues while at the NSA until 1992, when she moved to New York City. One of her early tv appearances was Russell Simmons original Def Comedy Jam in the early 90s, where she shared the stage with Adele Givens, JB Smoove, DL Hughley, Bernie Mac, & Bill Bellamy. Working for the [[Hal Leonard Corporation|Hal Leonard]] publishing house, she edited a book entitled ''Polyrhythms – The Musician's Guide'', by [[Peter Magadini]].{{cite web|last=Magadini |first=Pete |url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/polyrhythms-the-musicians-guide/oclc/48903110/editions?referer=di&editionsView=true |title=Formats and Editions of Polyrhythms : the musician's guide |publisher=Worldcat.org |accessdate=November 2, 2013}} Her first big break came when opening for [[Chris Rock]] at [[Caroline's Comedy Club]]. In 1997, she joined the writing team on ''[[The Chris Rock Show]]''"[http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/InfoWeb?p_product=AWNB&p_theme=aggregated5&p_action=doc&p_docid=0EAFE88F24188F01&p_docnum=2&p_queryname=3 What's Up?]" ''San Antonio Express-News''. January 4, 1999. and also made many appearances on the show. The writing team was nominated for four [[Emmy Awards|Emmys]], and in 1999, won for Outstanding Writing for a Variety, Music, or Comedy Special. [[File:Ms. magazine Cover - Summer 2004.jpg|thumbnail|Sykes on the cover of ''[[Ms. magazine]]'' in 2004]] Since that time, she has appeared in such films as ''[[Pootie Tang]]''"[http://search.proquest.com/docview/409117118/D7C8F9E529164825PQ/1?accountid=46320 Also Opening]". ''The Washington Post''. June 29, 2001. p. T38. and on TV shows such as ''[[Curb Your Enthusiasm]]''.Shales, Tom. "[http://search.proquest.com/docview/409350511/ 'Curb Your Enthusiasm': We Can't! We Can't!] ''The Washington Post''. September 14, 2002. p. C1. In 2003, she starred in her own short-lived [[Fox network]] sitcom, ''[[Wanda at Large]]''.Gillies, Judith S. "[http://search.proquest.com/docview/409417182/ From Stand-Up to Sitcom]". ''The Washington Post''. March 23, 2003. p. Y7. The same year, Sykes appeared in an hour-long [[Comedy Central]] special, ''[[Tongue Untied (2003)|Tongue Untied]]''. That network also ranked her No. 70 on its list of the 100 greatest all-time stand ups. She served as a correspondent for [[Home Box Office|HBO]]'s ''[[Inside the NFL]]'',Baker, Jim. "[http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/InfoWeb?p_product=AWNB&p_theme=aggregated5&p_action=doc&p_docid=130944A929EFFA28&p_docnum=2&p_queryname=5 TV Plus: Play by Play HBO's NFL series got game]". ''Boston Herald''. September 16, 2001. hosted Comedy Central's popular show ''[[Premium Blend]]'', and voiced a recurring character named Gladys on Comedy Central's [[puppet]] show ''[[Crank Yankers]]''.Morrow, Terry. "[http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/InfoWeb?p_product=AWNB&p_theme=aggregated5&p_action=doc&p_docid=0F7D9B3076DD3470&p_docnum=7&p_queryname=6 Don't look for sweet on Sykes' new Fox sitcom]". ''The Knoxville News-Sentinel''. November 22, 2002. She also had a short-lived show on [[Comedy Central]] called ''[[Wanda Does It]]''."[http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/InfoWeb?p_product=AWNB&p_theme=aggregated5&p_action=doc&p_docid=104A274245769BDF&p_docnum=5&p_queryname=7 Television]". ''The Orlando Sentinel''. August 22, 2004. In addition to her film and television work, she is also an author. She wrote ''[[Yeah, I Said It]]'', a book of humorous observations on various topics, published in September 2004.Gonzalez, Erika. "[http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/InfoWeb?p_product=AWNB&p_theme=aggregated5&p_action=doc&p_docid=103FA1654FE5F82B&p_docnum=1&p_queryname=8 Deadpan and Dead-on Funny: Wanda Sykes Turns the Art of Wisecracks into Comedic Gold]". ''Rocky Mountain News''. July 16, 2004. In 2006, she landed a recurring role as Barb, opposite [[Julia Louis-Dreyfus]], on the sitcom ''[[The New Adventures of Old Christine]]'';Miller, Bruce R. "[http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/InfoWeb?p_product=AWNB&p_theme=aggregated5&p_action=doc&p_docid=12A31AB0A1EE4780&p_docnum=7&p_queryname=9 Christine' provides new thrills]". ''Sioux City Journal''. March 10, 2006. she became a series regular during the series' third season in 2008. She also guest starred in the ''[[Will & Grace]]'' episode "Buy, Buy Baby" in 2006.Wilson-Combs, Lana K. "[http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/InfoWeb?p_product=AWNB&p_theme=aggregated5&p_action=doc&p_docid=111B86BB332EF760&p_docnum=15&p_queryname=13 Sykes puts sweet smell of success into Stella the skunk]". ''The Oakland Tribune''. Friday, May 19, 2006. She provided voices for the [[2006 in film|2006 films]] ''[[Over the Hedge (film)|Over the Hedge]]'',Chaney, Jen. "[http://search.proquest.com/docview/410022939/ Just Wild About Wanda Sykes]". ''The Washington Post''. May 19, 2006. T49. ''[[Barnyard (film)|Barnyard]]'', and ''[[Brother Bear 2]]''. She had a part in ''[[My Super Ex-Girlfriend]]'' and after playing in ''[[Evan Almighty]]'', had a bit part in ''[[License to Wed]]''. Sykes' first [[HBO]] Comedy Special, entitled ''Wanda Sykes: [[Sick and Tired (2006)|Sick & Tired]]'', premiered on October 14, 2006; it was nominated for a [[59th Primetime Emmy Awards|2007 Emmy Award]].{{Citation | title = Complete List of 2007 Emmy Nominations |agency=Associated Press | date = July 19, 2007 | url = http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,289974,00.html | accessdate = November 27, 2009 }} In 2008, she performed as part of [[Cyndi Lauper]]'s [[True Colors Tour 2008|True Colors Tour]] for [[LGBT rights]]. In October 2008, Wanda Sykes appeared in a television ad for the [[Think Before You Speak Campaign]], an advertising campaign by [[GLSEN]] aimed at curbing [[homophobia|homophobic]] slang in youth communities. In the 30-second spot, she uses humor to scold a teenager for saying "that's so gay" when he really means "that is so bad".{{cite web | last = Juergens | first = Brian | title = Hilary Duff and Wanda Sykes on "That's so gay": Knock it off! | publisher = After Elton | date = October 8, 2008 | url = http://www.afterelton.com/blog/brianjuergens/hilary-duff-wanda-sykes-on-thats-so-gay-knock-it-off | accessdate = November 27, 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thinkb4youspeak.com |title=Think before you speak. Don't say "That's So Gay." |publisher=Thinkb4youspeak.com |date=December 21, 2009 |accessdate=November 2, 2013}} In March 2009, it was announced that Sykes would be the host of a new late-night talk show on Saturdays on ''Fox'', ''[[The Wanda Sykes Show]]'' which was scheduled to premiere November 7, 2009.{{Cite press release|title=Wanda Returns to Fox!|publisher=Fox|date=April 1, 2009|url=http://www.wandasykes.com/press_pop.php?pressReleaseID=32|accessdate=November 27, 2009}}{{Cite news|last=Ostrow|first=Joanne|title=Wanda Sykes brings her sass to late night|newspaper=The Denver Post|date=November 7, 2009|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/tv/ci_13723269|accessdate=November 27, 2009}} In April 2009, she was named in ''[[Out (magazine)|Out]]'' magazine's "Annual Power 50 List", landing at number 35. In May 2009, Sykes was the featured entertainer for the annual [[White House Correspondents' Association]] dinner, becoming both the first African American woman and the first [[closeted|openly]] LGBT person to get the role. [[Cedric the Entertainer]] had been the first African American to become the featured entertainer in 2005. At this event, Sykes made controversial headlines as she responded to conservative radio talk show host [[Rush Limbaugh]]'s comments regarding President [[Barack Obama]]. Limbaugh, in reference to Obama's presidential agenda, had said "I hope he fails". In response, Sykes quipped: "I hope his [Limbaugh's] kidneys fail, how 'bout that? Needs a little waterboarding, that's what he needs."Bolcer, Julie. "[http://www.advocate.com/printArticle.aspx?id=73773 Wanda Sykes Rips Into Rush Limbaugh]{{dead link|date=March 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}" ''[[The Advocate]]''. May 11, 2009. (Retrieved May 11, 2009)
Farah, Joseph, "[http://www.creators.com/opinion/joseph-farah/long-live-rush-and-free-speech.html Long Live Rush – And Free Speech] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131023095437/http://www.creators.com/opinion/joseph-farah/long-live-rush-and-free-speech.html |date=October 23, 2013 }}", Creators Syndicate, 2009. Her second comedy special, ''Wanda Sykes: [[I'ma Be Me (2009)|I'ma Be Me]]'' premiered on HBO in October 2009. November 2009 saw the premier of ''The Wanda Sykes Show'', which starts with a monologue and continues with a panel discussion in a similar format to [[Bill Maher]]'s shows ''[[Real Time with Bill Maher]]'' and ''[[Politically Incorrect]]''. She appeared as [[Miss Hannigan]] in a professional theatre production of ''[[Annie (musical)|Annie]]'' at The Media Theatre in Media, PA, a suburb 25 minutes southwest of Philadelphia. Her first appearance in a musical, she played the role from November 23 – December 12, 2010, and again from January 12–23, 2011. She voices the Witch in the ''[[Bubble Guppies]]'' episode "Bubble Puppy's Fin-tastic Fairlytale Adventure". In 2012, Sykes role the voice of Granny in ''[[Ice Age: Continental Drift]]'', and In 2016, she was returned voice of Granny in ''[[Ice Age: Collision Course]]'' from the Blue Sky Studios' "Ice Age movies". In May 2013, Sykes was a featured entertainer at [[Olivia Travel]]'s 40th anniversary Music & Comedy Festival in [[Punta Cana]], [[Dominican Republic]].{{cite press release|url=http://www.olivia.com/connect/Press/OliviaPress/2012/Olivia40thLeisureRelease.pdf |title= Olivia Launches Milestone 40th Anniversary with Unparalleled Entertainment and Itineraries on Four 2013 Vacations: San Francisco-based lesbian travel company adds second Southern Caribbean cruise and second Punta Cana resort vacation due to high demand |publisher= [[Olivia Travel|Olivia]] |year= 2012 |accessdate=November 2, 2013 }} In 2013, Sykes appeared in eight episodes of Amazon's ''[[Alpha House]]'', a political comedy series written by ''[[Doonesbury]]'' creator [[Garry Trudeau]].{{cite news|last=Goodman|first=Tim|title= Alpha House: TV Review|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/alpha-house-tv-review-656034|accessdate=July 24, 2014|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=November 14, 2013}} Sykes plays Rosalyn DuPeche, a Democratic Senator from Illinois and the next door neighbor of four Republican senators living together in a house on Capitol Hill. Sykes also appeared in Season Two, which became available in October 2014. The series was canceled after the second season. In 2018, it was announced that Sykes would be the head writer for the reboot of Roseanne.{{cite web |url=http://afropunk.com/2018/04/wanda-sykes-is-roseanne-head-writer-does-that-mean-theres-hope-or-should-we-be-appalled/ |title=Wanda Sykes is ‘Roseanne’ head writer, does that mean there’s hope or should we be appalled? |date=April 3, 2018 |website=AfroPunk |access-date=May 17, 2018}} This has attracted significant controversy due to Roseanne's far-right and conspiratorial views.{{cite web |url=https://www.vox.com/culture/2018/3/30/17174720/roseanne-2018-reboot-controversy-trump-explained-review |title=The Roseanne revival, and the argument over how TV depicts Trump supporters, explained |date=March 30, 2018 |website=Vox.com |access-date=May 17, 2018}} On May 29, 2018, Sykes announced on Twitter that she would no longer be working on the series after a (now deleted) controversial Twitter post by [[Roseanne Barr]] about [[Valerie Jarrett]].{{cite web |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-44294997 |title= Roseanne Barr sorry for comparing Obama aide to ape |date= May 29, 2018 |accessdate= May 29, 2018 |publisher= BBC News}}{{cite web |last=Gonzalez |first=Sandra |date= 2018-05-29 |url= https://edition.cnn.com/2018/05/29/entertainment/wanda-sykes-roseanne/index.html |title= Wanda Sykes quits 'Roseanne' - CNN |publisher= Edition.cnn.com |accessdate=2018-05-30}} ==Personal life== [[File:Wanda Sykes.jpg |thumb |right |upright|Sykes in September 2004.]] Sykes was married to record producer [[Dave Hall (record producer)|Dave Hall]] from 1991 to 1998. In November 2008, she publicly [[coming out|came out]] as a lesbian while at a [[same-sex marriage]] rally in [[Las Vegas, Nevada |Las Vegas]] regarding [[California Proposition 8 (2008)|Proposition 8]].{{Citation |last= McKinley |first=Jessie |title=Across U.S., Big Rallies for Same-Sex Marriage |newspaper= The New York Times |date=November 15, 2008 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/16/us/16protest.html?_r=1&ref=us |accessdate= Nov 27, 2009}} A month earlier, Sykes had married her partner Alex Niedbalski, a French woman,{{cite news |url= http://blogs.windsorstar.com/entertainment/sykes-doesnt-bring-the-kids-to-work-just-the-stories |author=Ted Shaw |title= Sykes doesn’t bring the kids to work; just the stories |publisher= Windsor Star |date= April 15, 2015 |accessdate= July 16, 2015}} whom she had met in 2006. The couple also became parents on April 27, 2009, when Alex gave birth to a pair of fraternal twins, daughter Olivia Lou and son Lucas Claude.{{cite news |author=Julie Jordan |url= http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20278746,00.html |title= Wanda Sykes Becomes Mom of Twins! |work=People |date=May 13, 2009 |accessdate= May 13, 2009}} Sykes only came out to her conservative mother Marion and father Harry when she was 40, who both initially had difficulty accepting her homosexuality. They declined to attend her wedding with Alex, which led to a brief period of estrangement; they have since reconciled with Sykes and are now proud grandparents to the couple's children.{{cite news|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/showbiz/439668/Wanda-Sykes-fell-out-with-parents-after-coming-out|title=Wanda Sykes fell out with parents after 'coming out'|work=Express|date=October 28, 2013|accessdate=July 25, 2014}} During a September 19, 2011, appearance on ''[[The Ellen DeGeneres Show]]'', Sykes announced that she had been diagnosed earlier in the year with [[ductal carcinoma in situ]] (DCIS). Although DCIS is a non-invasive "stage zero breast cancer", Sykes had elected to have a bilateral [[mastectomy]] in order to lower her chances of getting breast cancer.Silverman, Stephen M. [http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20531010,00.html?xid=rss-topheadlines "Wanda Sykes: I Had a Double Mastectomy"]. ''[[People (magazine)|People]]''. September 23, 2011 Sykes splits time living in both Los Angeles and [[Media, Pennsylvania]], a suburb of Philadelphia."Molly Eichel, "Wanda Sykes loves the small-town life of Media", ''Philadelphia Daily News'', May 1, 2013." [http://www.philly.com/philly/entertainment/celebrities/20130501_Wanda_Sykes_loves_the_small-town_life_of_Media.html] ===Activism=== Sykes publicly expressed being devastated when California voters passed state [[Proposition 8]]. She said: "with the legislation that they passed, I can’t sit by and just watch. I just can’t do it."{{cite news|first1=Christopher|last1=Lisotta|first2=Corey|last2=Scholibo|url=http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid66219.asp|title=Wanda Sykes Comes Out Amid Passing of Prop. 8|work=The Advocate|date=November 15, 2008|accessdate=November 17, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090105194121/http://www2.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid66219.asp|archivedate=January 5, 2009|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news|author=Sarah Warn|title=Wanda Sykes Comes Out as Gay and Married|url=http://www.afterellen.com/people/2008/11/wanda-sykes-comes-out|date=November 15, 2008|accessdate=November 22, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081203200016/http://www.afterellen.com/people/2008/11/wanda-sykes-comes-out|archivedate=December 3, 2008|df=mdy-all}} She has continued to be active in [[same-sex marriage]] issues hosting events and emceeing fundraisers. She has also worked with [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]] on promoting dog anti-chaining legislation in her home state.Tracy Agnew,"[http://www.suffolknewsherald.com/2013/02/15/celebrity-wants-anti-chaining-law/ Celebrity Wants Anti-Chaining Law]," ''Suffolk News Herald'', February 15, 2013. She has been an outspoken supporter of [[Detroit]]'s [[Ruth Ellis Center]] after the organization's staff sent Sykes a letter asking her to visit during her 2010 tour's stop in Detroit.{{cite news | url=http://www.pridesource.com/article.html?article=42165 | title=Wanda Sykes visits Ruth Ellis Center | work=[[Between the Lines (newspaper)|Between the Lines]] | date=July 8, 2010 | accessdate=August 1, 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131025020937/http://www.pridesource.com/article.html?article=42165 | archivedate=October 25, 2013 | df=mdy-all }}{{cite journal | url=http://www.hourdetroit.com/Hour-Detroit/September-2012/No-Laughing-Matter/ | title=Q&A: Wanda Sykes, Ruth Ellis Center Fundraiser Host | author=Mercer, Monica | journal=Hour Detroit |date=September 2012}}{{cite news | url=http://www.advocate.com/youth/2012/10/04/invaluable-lgbt-youth-center-detroit-has-friend-wanda | title=Detroit's Invaluable LGBT Youth Center Has a Friend in Wanda | work=[[The Advocate]] | date=October 4, 2012 | accessdate=August 1, 2013 | author=Broverman, Neal}} ==Awards== Sykes has been nominated for seven Primetime Emmys, with one win (in 1999) for "Outstanding Writing for a Variety, Music or Comedy Special". In 2001, she won the American Comedy Award for "Outstanding Female Stand Up Comic". She won a Comedy Central Commie Award for "Funniest TV Actress in 2003".{{cite news|title=Wanda Sykes Biography|url=http://comedians.comedycentral.com/wanda-sykes|work=Comedy Central|date=May 11, 2009|accessdate=May 11, 2009}} In 2010 she won the [[GLAAD Stephen F. Kolzak Award]].[http://www.afterellen.com/blog/karmankregloe/wanda-sykes-accepts-her-glaad-award Wanda Sykes accepts her GLAAD award] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110829061947/http://www.afterellen.com/blog/karmankregloe/wanda-sykes-accepts-her-glaad-award |date=August 29, 2011 }} After Ellen, April 20, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvweek.com/blogs/tvbizwire/2010/02/glaad-to-honor-wanda-sykes-wit.php |title="TV Week GLAAD to honor Wanda Sykes", February 2010 |publisher=Tvweek.com |accessdate=November 2, 2013}} In 2015 she won the Activism in the Arts honor at the Triumph Awards.{{cite web|url=http://goodblacknews.org/2015/09/14/john-legend-tyrese-gibson-wanda-sykes-honored-at-2015-triumph-awards/ |title=John Legend, Tyrese Gibson, Wanda Sykes Honored at 2015 Triumph Awards |publisher=Good Black News |accessdate=September 15, 2015}} ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Film ! Role ! Notes |- | 1998 | ''[[Tomorrow Night (film)|Tomorrow Night]]'' | Wanda (Mel's Date) | credited as ''Wanda Sykes-Hall'' |- | 2000 |''[[Nutty Professor II: The Klumps]]'' | Chantal | |- | rowspan=2|2001 | ''[[Down to Earth (2001 film)|Down to Earth]]'' | Wanda | |- | ''[[Pootie Tang]]'' | Biggie Shorty | |- | 2005 | ''[[Monster-in-Law]]'' | Ruby | |- | rowspan=7|2006 |''[[The Adventures of Brer Rabbit]]'' | Sister Moon | [[Direct-to-video]]
[[voice acting|Voice]] |- |''[[Over the Hedge (film)|Over the Hedge]]'' | Stella | Voice
Nominated – [[Annie Award for Voice Acting in a Feature Production]] |- |''[[Clerks II]]'' | Angry Customer | |- |''[[My Super Ex-Girlfriend]]'' | Carla Dunkirk | |- |''[[Barnyard (film)|Barnyard]]'' | Bessy | Voice |- |''[[Brother Bear 2]]'' |Innoko | Direct-to-video

Year ! Title ! Role !
